Award.AwardTitle: NetSE: Medium: Collaborative Research: Privacy Preserving Social Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The success of the future Internet will not be measured by performance alone, but by its social and societal effects that alter our quality of life. The next-generation Internet must connect not only machines but also users: families and friends, representatives and rights advocates. There are immense technical challenges in facilitating communication while protecting user privacy and guarding their security. We address three key challenges. First, we apply user-focused research into developing practical secure communication between friends, laying the groundwork for social messaging without trusting centralized authorities to provide identities. Second, we develop advanced cryptographic techniques for processing private data without divulging it to application providers, placing private social applications on a solid theoretical foundation. Finally, we propose to fundamentally change how cooperation is encouraged and misbehavior is punished in distributed applications by embedding social network data into the design of applications.

This work has important broader impacts. Social networking is incredibly popular and maintaining privacy is a significant problem within these systems. The desire for privacy prevents individuals from participating fully and makes those who do participate vulnerable to various problems including potential identity theft. Because of the importance of the problem and problem domain, the results of our research will have significant public impact. Graduate and undergraduate students working on this proposal will gain experience with social applications, evaluating cryptographic protocols, and building systems that combine social data. We have actively involved undergraduate students in our research, and expect to continue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The success of the future Internet will not be measured by performance
alone, but by its social and societal effects that alter our quality
of life. Modern online interactions are characterized by two salient
features: they often involve social networks, and they are often
conducted using mobile devices. This project focused on creating
basic security and privacy algorithms for secure social interactions
that, e.g., enable users to authenticate to a service provider while
maintaining their anonymity from that provider. Our work also focused
on safely enabling new opportunities using mobile devices. Based on
early results, a later part of the project focused on mobile device
power management.

Intellectual Merit:

We have developed fundamental techniques for enabling
privacy-preserving mobile-mobile device interactions, subscription
services, and interactions on social networks. Prior approaches
either stored all user data, including potentially sensitive
information such as location and activity, on a trusted server or
implemented device-to-device communication that was susceptible to
tracking. Our techniques enable the replication of existing
mobile-social applications, without divulging sensitive information to
third parties or trackers. At the same time, users are able to
securely recognize friends and interact using mobile-social
applications. Critically, our techniques are extremely efficient
(orders of magnitude more efficient than previous work), and can
directly be implemented on current mobile devices.


In the course of developing systems for mobile-social applications, we
obtained extremely fine-grained power measurements for mobile systems.
Based on observations in these measurements, we have developed a new
power management mode that reduces power consumption of periodic tasks
in existing systems by 1.5 - 5x.

Broader Impact:

Our work on privacy-preserving mobile-social applications enables new
applications and new modes of user-interaction. We have demonstrated
uses by implementing and measuring new applications. The follow-up
work on power management improves the battery-life of existing mobile
devices, regardless of their use for mobile-social applications.
Given the pervasiveness of mobile devices, this discovery has broad
impact beyond social networks.
